comments.commentBody: That choice alone proves he does not want to answer under oath,so he should be forced out!

Do you never file your own taxes? Tax returns don't show things like that. If Trump borrowed money...it was to a dozen shell corporations in tax havens, buried under tons of legalese.

His returns are not going to say "I.O.U. Vladimir Putin $100 million in exchange for messing up the 2016 elections".

Come on! go get a copy of a tax form, and read it. It doesn't show the kind of information you think (or wish) it would.

Don't forget Reagan made a deal with Iran to keep the hostages during the 1980 election, in order to squash Carter.

Typical Republican power-mad TREASON
VBG!

You are opposed to Trump because of "Russian hacking".

Ergo, you call to hack Trump's PRIVATE tax returns within the IRS -- making the IRS both corrupt and vulnerable. Do you want your tax returns published to the world? No privacy, it's all public info?

Calling on the IRS to be hacked is saying you want YOUR OWN NATION to have no control over private documents or citizen's tax records! Just to try and attack Donald Trump.

Be careful what you wish for.

Accepting reality, that the Russians played a role, with Trump and his team's sellout for the win and money, what was the "quid pro quo?

Was it Crimea? Was it the dismantling of NATO? can't be something as simple as the lifting of sanctions? a compromised president?

what was their end game?

My heart broke when I read this. It couldn't be! ! My sister-in-law met Amy at an ALA conference and asked her to sign a copy of the book that became our household favorite. Little Pea, with a sweet inscription to the child we called Little Sweet Pea.  Thank you Amy, for being so generous and humorous and lovely, even now.  Wishing you godspeed. I wish you could know how many nights we spent giggling over your books. Your husband married a hell of a woman,  and you will be one tough act to follow. Love and light.
(I sobbed)

What a lovely thing to write. I am sad and happy at the same time.
I am sure your love was true and Jason was your soul mate.
i wish you peace.

Chuck From Ohio
He is a lucky guy.  Good luck on the Astral Plane.  This is heartbreakingly moving.  You were both very lucky in life.

You are in a perfect position to run for office Gail. Let's burn everybody at the stake if we don't agree with his policies. The so called Russian crisis investigation started well before the election process began. We have no evidence that any crime has been committed by either administration. Yes, there has been evidence in the past of the Russians interfearing with elections around the world. Yes it appears they hacked the DNC and exposed some stupid emails that were written by DNC senior officials. Let's get to the bottom of this.... I agree.
Regarding Sessions, he recused himself of any involvement in the aforementioned investigation. Let it play out or is it more fun to paint a tall tale about the GOP working with Russian operatives to hack the DNC so they could win?

Anything is possible - that is why we have to let it play out - I'm not judging one way or the other until the water clears. You have already taken sides which I think, is premature and dangerous, because you demonstrate no objectivity. I am not registered with either party and truthfully - they both put me to shame.

Roger Cohen's column yesterday on Trump's contempt for the republic says it all, and what he said extends throughout this so-called administration.  I firmly believe that the facts of the engagement of Trump operatives with Russia run deep and wide, and will prove damning.  I also believe that many GOP congressmen have been made aware of the facts, know they must lead to impeachment, and are intent on dragging this out as long as possible.  It is up to the American people to set aside partisan ideology and defend the Constitution at the polls in eighteen months.  it won't be defended otherwise.  I just hope we're up to the job.  If not...

Dear Amy,

I am in tears for you and your courage, and for loving your husband so much. So much that you wrote and expressed the most selfless letter.

I loved my husband so much I always said to be with him I would even live in a one room shack. People laughed it off but I would look at him each night and thank God for a man that loved me as much or more than I loved him. At 31 and 5 months after we married, a tragic accident took his life. now 43 it has taken me this long to accept. But not many understand when you have the love you have and I had - for me anyway it has been the hardest and longest journey to release him. Amy, you are a woman I could never be. This love you two have people look for so long and never achieve. You and your husband are so blessed and I cannot imagine with the physical and emotional pain you feel. Yes, you have given a gift to your husband by just writing this. Grief is different for all and I pray you both experience peace and continue to let others this is what love is about.

If things were different and it had been me instead of him, yes I would want him to find love and comfort and a family of his own. For me it hit hard, still alone and with my rescues I go on. Now not the joyous person I was. But I will say again you sharing your true love is a gift to us all, an inspiration that love still exists.

Thank you for sharing. You are all in my prayers.

Mary Beth
And with you. Best wishes, Carrie.
You are such an amazing woman that think I'm falling in love with you (but your husband sounds fab too). I'll look for the brightest star in the sky.......

In *his* column, Jeff Chen complained about TAYLOR SCHILLING, saying "I do like that the NYT is giving exposure to an on-the-cusp-of-greatness star, but it felt more like being educated than being entertained." I don't know about you, but I don't mind -- and in fact look forward to -- being "educated" by late week puzzles. I don't watch "Orange..." but I could certainly discern Ms. Schilling from the crosses, and I may even remember her name (as some of you who watch the show but don't follow soccer may now remember my gimme Manuel Neuer.

I also did not know who played PIAF, I have not played on SPORCLE, I know every exhibit in the Museum of Science and Industry (of 55 years ago), I did not know the TSE volume, the author of the palindrome, the IHOP slogan, or the MLK quote, and I've never been to Nikolskoye (but I kind of like the music).

I had a very pleasant time educating myself with the crosses.
We all know different stuff.  PIAF was one of my few gimmes, and I hesitated to put in TREVI at first as I thought it too obvious for a Saturday

.
@ Barry Ancona:

My parents go to every large family gathering. This includes "Family Reunions" that are reunions for branches of the family that lost touch with my parents' branches during WWII; for the rest of us, they are not "re" at all. Just unions.

My mother's parents went to Alabama to run a family-owned store right after marrying, because my grandmother's union didn't guarantee her job security unless she was unmarried. Then the family entrepreneur opened another store not too far north fo the border, in TENN, so they managed that store for 10 years. Hence, my mom was born in Tennessee.

The Alabama branch of the family left Alabama one by one, or died. So there are family outposts in places like West Virginia. Family reunions are held in these outposts. One of the ones my parents attended was in Tulsa.

So my parents have never been to heaven ... but they been to Oklahoma. (And no, my mom doesn't remember Tennessee; they moved before she was old enough to store reliable memories. My grandmother had a sister in the union who told her they were accepting married women. She went back to her old industry and collected a pension almost until my mom was 60.)
A good example is the Thrift Savings Plan for federal employees.  Lowest cost program in the United States with simple index and lifestyle funds.  It works.
Absolutely brilliant writing. Clear, precise, not an extra word. Leaves me wanting more. Thank you Amy.

Sessions must go. An honorable person would have no reason to lie. There is nothing to investigate or debate. His legal standing as a sitting Senator at the time of the admitted meeting is irrelevant. That there were admittedly contacts between and among Trump associates with Russian officials before January 20 is a separate and obviously serious concern. The fact that Sessions did not testify truthfully is all that matters. That Trump equivocated is also beside the point, but no less serious a concern.
Jason is the lucky one, having been loved and appreciated so completely. Thank you so much, Amy, for sharing your love story.

My heart goes out to the writer as what she and her husband are going through is tragically beyond words. However, I would like to respectfully provide a contrary opinion from the surviving spouse that may help people understand terminal illness and grief.

My spouse and I were together for 27 years. Sixteen of those years were spent dealing with catastrophic illness. The end did not come quickly and the suffering was unbearable to witness. Had my spouse tried to find me another partner during that time, I would have been devastated. Looking at life beyond my spouse's death during those tragic days would have been unthinkable. My love and life were focused on being the strength and support that my spouse needed. The concept of finding another partner never crossed my mind even months and two years beyond the day we said our final goodbye. Grieving is a critical part of life and relationships. It cannot be fast-forwarded. It is a slow and painful process. It requires wandering in unknown territory.

The reality is we are all terminal. Some of us simply reach the airport departure gate before others do. My advice is allow your loved ones to be with you and love you. They will find their way after your death. None of us have control. The fact of the matter is that many widows and widowers choose to remain single. That's OK. We must each find our own path in this life but we must be allowed to do so in our own time.

Blessings!

Trump is solely responsible for the rise of suspicions about his ties to Russia.

His failure to release his tax returns and his unusual admiration of Putin and softer stance on Russia gave rise to the initial suspicion that perhaps he had financial reasons for his stance. And his categorical denials which turn out to be fake don't help either.

The Republican Party should never have permitted him to run without subjecting him to extreme vetting.

Talking with foreign diplomats, even from less than friendly countries, is routine and important. But Trump affiliates and surrogates would have to be brain dead not to realize that all contacts with Russians would be subject to heightened scrutiny because of Russian interference in the election campaign. So carry on with the contacts but do so openly and within normal protocol. And don't deny it, or forget about it.

Improving relations with Russia is a good goal. But what is the cost of doing so? Trump has been vague and vacillating on this.

Ironically, because of Russian interference in the election and Trump's failure to allay suspicions of financial entanglements, any attempt by the Trump Administration to improve relations with Russia will be met with suspicion.

The Sessions affair is important, since it shows that Trump is loyal to his early supporters, no matter what their qualifications or prior actions might be. Deeper problems are the domestic policies. There the GOP are planning to reduce the health care, and reduce the taxes of the wealthy. To make up for these policies, Trump and the GOP want to tax imports. These are not amusing, but are tremendous changes in the way US citizens live.

Issues that involve both domestic and international issues are the attacks by Trump on the EU and Germany. That Trump seems to withdraw from Europe and repell Europeans is a policy that helps Russia. Taken together, all of these show that the Trump administration is either a tool of Putin's or completely incompetent.

I read this in the midst of a study break. On the brink of turning 31 and yet I'm still in school to become a physician this article really reached out to me. I've spent countless hours studying when I could have spent it living all in the hopes that one day when I finish school that I will be able to. This was a wonderful reminder to not take things for granted. To live life to the fullest and to cherish those closest to you. The love you have shown for your husband in this article is truly inspirational. I wish both you and your loved ones the best.

I don't know what to say, dear Amy, you have given so much.
I have cried and laughed and talked excitedly to my dog about you.
What you wrote has brought up everything in this loving, changing, constantly shifting universe and still planted something permanent.
I wish you as much as you can hold and experience and share with your beautiful family, in your sacred life.
love and thanks.
